label: absolutive case
description: A [case](#case) used to indicate the [patient](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/patient#Noun) or [experiencer](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/experiencer) of a [verb](#verb)'s action.

label: future tense
description: The [tense](#tense) of a [verb](#verb) used to refer to an event that has not yet happened, is expected to happen in the future, or might never happen. In English it is formed by using [_will_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/will#English) or [_shall_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/shall#English) before the verb, as in _I will go home tomorrow_.

label: feminine
description: Feminine; said of a word belonging to the feminine [gender](#gender), which is usually contrasted with the [masculine](#masculine) gender, and also often with a [neuter](#neuter) gender.

label: masculine
description: Belonging to the male grammatical [gender](#gender), in languages that have gender distinctions.

label: neuter
description: Of neuter [gender](#gender): having a form which is not [masculine](#masculine) nor [feminine](#feminine); or having a form which is not of [common gender](#common_gender).

label: admirative
description: A verb form similar to [mirative](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/mirative), found primarily in some languages of the Balkan sprachbund (i.e. namely Albanian, Bulgarian and Macedonian), which expresses surprise, irony, doubt, or reportedness on the part of the speaker.

label: annexed state
description: In [Berber languages](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Category:Berber_languages), a grammatical [case](#case) or [state](#state) of the [noun](#noun), part of a binary opposition with the [free state](#free_state). The annexed state is characterized by modification of the noun's initial syllable: in Northern Berber, [masculine](#masculine) nouns typically take a _w-_ or _y-_ prefix (e.g. [_argaz_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/argaz#Kabyle) (“man”) → [_wergaz_](https://en.wiktionary.org/w/index.php?title=wergaz&action=edit&redlink=1)), while [feminine](#feminine) nouns may lose their initial vowel. The annexed state marks a noun in a [dependency](#dependency) relationship: after most [prepositions](#preposition), as the [subject](#subject) of a [verb](#verb), after numerals, or as a [determiner](#determiner) of another noun. Also called [**construct state**](#construct_state). / Contrast [_free state_](#free_state).

label: dual
description: A [grammatical number](#number) that indicates exactly two items or individuals. Usually contrasts with [singular](#singular_number) and [plural](#plural_number).

label: plural
description: A [grammatical number](#number) that indicates multiple items or individuals. Most languages contrast it with [singular](#singular_number), and plural indicates two or more. Some languages also possess the [dual](#dual_number) or even [trial](#trial_number) numbers; in these instances the plural indicates more than the highest specific number.

label: singular
description: A [grammatical number](#number) that indicates exactly one item or individual. Usually contrasts with [plural](#plural_number), and, in some languages, with [dual](#dual_number).

label: past tense
description: The [tense](#tense) of a [verb](#verb) used to refer to an event, transaction, or occurrence that did happen or has happened, or an object that existed, at a point in time before now. An English example is [_saw_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/saw#English) in _I saw my friend yesterday_.

label: present tense
description: The [tense](#tense) of a [verb](#verb) used primarily to refer to an event, transaction, or occurrence happening now or at the present time. The verb [_see_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/see#English) in _I see my friend in the window_ is in the present tense. In many languages, including English, the present tense may also be used to refer to past or future events in certain contexts: _My plane leaves tomorrow morning_ (where [_leave_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/leave#English) is a present verb that refers to the future), or: _John Lennon dies of gunshot wounds_ (as in a headline, where [_dies_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/dies#English) is a present verb that refers to the past; see [historical present](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/historical_present)). While such uses are somewhat exceptional in English, the present tense is used much more widely in many languages. For example, the German present tense also covers some or most of the uses of the English future (_I will do_) and present perfect (_I have done_).

label: infinitive
description: A non-[finite](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/finite) verb form considered [neutral](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/neutral) with respect to [inflection](#inflection); depending on language variously found used with [auxiliary verbs](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/auxiliary_verb), in [subordinate clauses](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/subordinate_clause), or acting as a [gerund](#gerund), and often as the [dictionary form](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/dictionary_form). In English, the infinitive is formed with the word [_to_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/to#English), e.g. to [_read_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/read#English).

label: gerund
description: Any of various non-finite [verb](#verb) forms in various languages. In English, a "[gerund](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gerund#Gerunds_in_English)" refers to a verb in its [_-ing_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-ing#English) form when used in a way that resembles the use of a [noun](#noun). Despite showing noun-like behavior in the context of the surrounding sentence, gerunds show verbal behavior in the context of their own internal clause: they can take direct objects or be modified by adverbs. In this way, gerunds are distinguished from deverbal nouns ending in _-ing,_ which occur in noun phrases that can take determiners or be modified by adjectives. For example, "manufacturing" is a gerund in the following sentence: "Efficiently manufacturing this device is difficult." It is a [verbal noun](#verbal_noun) (not a gerund) in this sentence: "The efficient manufacturing of this device is difficult." In other languages, gerund can refer to a form that often functions as an [adverb](#adverb) to form [adverbial](#adverbial) phrases or the continuous tense.
